description: Destructive Dilemma is the contrapositive form of Constructive Dilemma. If we know "if P then Q" AND "if R then S", and we also know "not Q or not S" is true, then we can conclude "not P or not R" must be true. This works by denying the consequents to deny the antecedents. This is a double-operation rule requiring two premises.

problems.solution: Apply Destructive Dilemma directly: since either ¬Q or ¬S is true, we can conclude ¬P or ¬R.
Apply Destructive Dilemma with different variables.
Apply Destructive Dilemma - order of negated disjunction doesn't matter, result may be reversed.
Apply Destructive Dilemma where one antecedent is a conjunction.
Apply Destructive Dilemma where consequents are conjunctions.
First apply Conjunction to combine the two implications, then Destructive Dilemma.
Apply Destructive Dilemma to get ¬P ∨ ¬R, then use Disjunctive Syllogism with P to derive ¬R.
Apply Destructive Dilemma with complex disjunctions as antecedents.
Complex multi-step: use Destructive Dilemma strategically with the available conditionals and negations to derive the conditional conclusion.
